message_1:
Let's consider the following situation: 

At a party, there are 10 guests and a cake is served. Each guest has the option to choose one of the 3 flavors of the cake. Modal logic tells us that a proposition about the cake's flavor can be expressed as a modal formula. Suppose we define the modal operator "Pl" as "at least p of the guests have chosen flavor l". 

Now, let p be the proposition that "at least 4 guests have chosen flavor A", and q be the proposition that "at least 5 guests have chosen flavor B". Write a modal formula in terms of p and q that expresses the statement "at least 2 guests have chosen flavor C".
message_2:
Let r be the proposition that "at least 2 guests have chosen flavor C". Since there are 10 guests in total, we can express r in terms of p and q as follows:

¬(Pl(4, A) ∧ Pl(5, B))

This means that it is not the case that both at least 4 guests have chosen flavor A and at least 5 guests have chosen flavor B. In other words, if at least 2 guests have chosen flavor C, then it is not possible for both p and q to be true simultaneously.
